facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1953 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1953. Appeal under Article 132 1

facts.text: Appeal under Article 132 of Constitution from High Court of Allahabad judgment dated 1st October 1953 in Civil Miscellaneous Writ No. 379 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 1st October, 1953, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Civil Miscel

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ application on 1st October 1953 but granted leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment dated the 1st October, 1953, dismissed the application but, as the case involved a substantial question of the interpretation of the Constitution, the High Court granted leave to the appellant to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under Article 226 in Allahabad High Court to quash President's order dated 17th April 1953 ordering compulsory retirement after completing 25 years qualifying service.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of an application made by the appellant to the High Court of Allahabad under, article 226 of the Constitution praying for an appropriate writ quashing the order made by the President of India on the 17th April, 1953, ordering the companypulsory retirement of the appellant who had companypleted 25 years qualifying service.

facts.text: Appellant passed Civil Engineering degree examination from Thomason College, Roorkee in 1922, stood first in merit, awarded Gold Medal and prizes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant passed his Civil Engineering degree examinaion from the Thomason College. Roorkee, in 1922. He stood first in order of merit and carried away the Gold Medal and other prizes awarded to the best student of that year.

facts.text: Appellant appointed by Secretary of State for India in Council to Indian Service of Engineers as Assistant Executive Engineer effective 20th October 1923.

anchor.surface_text: He was appointed by the Secretary of State for India in Council to the Indian Service of Engineers as an Assistant Executive Engineer with effect from the 20th October, 1923.

facts.text: Conditions of appellant's appointment recorded in letter from India Office, London dated 13th February 1924.

anchor.surface_text: The companyditions governing the appellants terms of appointment, promotion, leave, pension, etc., will be found recorded in a letter issued from India Office, London, on the 13th February, 1924.

facts.text: Appellant posted in United Provinces.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of that letter is annexed to the Petition filed under article 226. He was posted in ,the United Provinces.

facts.text: Appellant promoted to officiating Superintending Engineer in 1944.

anchor.surface_text: In 1944 the appellant was promoted to the rank of officiating Superintending Engineer.

facts.text: Fresh agreement entered between appellant, Governor of United Provinces and Governor General of India on 16th September 1948 confirming terms from 1924 letter.

anchor.surface_text: After the attainment of independence by India a fresh agreement was entered into by and between the appellant the Governor of the United Provinces and the Governor General of India on the 16th September, 1948 companyfirming the appellants terms of appointment companytained in the letter of the 13th February, 1924.

facts.text: Appellant recommended by Chief Engineer for confirmation as Superintending Engineer but not confirmed, continued to officiate.

anchor.surface_text: At or about this time the appellant along with several other officers was recommended by the Chief Engineer for companyfirmation as Superintending Engineer. The appellant, however, was number companyfirmed but companytinued to officiate as Superintending Engineer until the time hereinafter stated.

facts.text: Public Works Department of U.P. Government addressed letter dated 4th January 1950 to Chief Engineer, Irrigation Branch U.P. to communicate show cause letter to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the 4th January, 1950, the Public Works Department of the U.P. Government addressed a letter to the Chief Engineer, Irrigation Branch U.P. requesting him to companymunicate the letter enclosed therewith to the appellant and to ask him to submit as early as possible whatever explanation he might desire to give.

facts.text: Show cause letter alleged appellant made systematic and gross overpayments to benefit contractors, spent public money for personal convenience, used devious methods; six instances listed.

anchor.surface_text: The enclosed letter called upon the appellant to show cause within three weeks why he should number-be companypulsorily retired under the provisions of article 465-A, Civil Service Regulations,as it appeared  1  that he had been making systematic and gross overpayments apparently for numberother reason than to benefit the companytractors companycerned and  2  that he had spent large amounts of public money for his own personal companyvenience and  3  that he had taken recourse to devious and unscrupulous methods. No less than, six instances on which these charges were based. were them set out.

facts.text: Appellant submitted explanations to show cause letter.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant submitted his explanations which, together with the Chief Engineers companyments thereon, were placed before the Union Public Service Commission.

facts.text: Union Public Service Commission concluded that five out of six charges proved.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission came to the companyclusion that five out of the six charges had been proved and submitted their report accordingly.

facts.text: President of India on 17th April 1953 ordered appellant to retire forthwith under Note 1 to Article 465-A Civil Service Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: On the 17th April, 1953, the President, after companysidering the case and the recommendations of the Commission, decided that the appellant should retire forthwith from service under Note I to article 465-A of the Civil Service Regulations.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition before Allahabad High Court on 24th April 1953 before President's order served.

anchor.surface_text: Before this order companyld be served on him the appellant on the 24th April, 1953, filed -before the Allahabad High Court a petition under article 226 of the Constitution praying that the order made by the President on the 17th April, 1953, be quashed

facts.text: Appellant had completed 25 years qualifying service.

anchor.surface_text: quashing the order made by the President of India on the 17th April, 1953, ordering the companypulsory retirement of the appellant who had companypleted 25 years qualifying service.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by DAS J. on 30 March 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. March 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS J.-This appeal arises out of an application made by the appellant to the High Court of Allahabad under, article 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Officers of Indian Service of Engineers included in officers mentioned in Article 349-A Civil Service Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: Officers of the Indian Service of Engineers are included amongst the officers mentioned in article 349-A of the Civil Service Regulations.

facts.text: Government reserves right to compulsorily retire officer after 25 years service if in public interest per Note 1 Article 465-A CSR.

anchor.surface_text: Note I.-Government retains an absolute right to retire any officer after he has companypleted twenty-five years qualifying service without giving any reasons, and numberclaim to special companypensation on this account will be entertained. This right will number be exercised except when it is in the public interest to dispense with the further services of an officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pension rules in Resolution 1085-E.A. of 15 Nov 1919 were published and in force before GIA 1919 passed on 23 Dec 1919, validated by s96B(4); applied to appellant appointed 1923; later CSR incorporation clarified scope without creating new rule; Note 1 retains pre-existing right.

holdings.text: A compulsory retirement does not amount to dismissal or removal and, therefore, does not attract the provisions of article 311 of the Constitution or of rule 55.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical tenure at pleasure qualified only for punitive dismissal/removal; compulsory retirement lacks stigma/imputation of misconduct, no loss of accrued pension/benefits unlike penalties under CSCAR r49; not listed as penalty; public interest after 25 years service.

holdings.text: Note I to article 465-A is not repugnant to article 311 as it does not involve removal/dismissal requiring opportunity to show cause.

anchor.surface_text: therefore, the order of the President cannot be challenged on the ground that the appellant had number been afforded full opportunity of showing cause against the action sought to be taken in regard to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compulsory retirement not punishment or removal; Art 311 safeguards apply only to cases with blame/stigma/loss of earned benefits; confirmed by evolution from GIA 1919/1935 to Constitution Arts 310/311 and precedents.

anchor.surface_text: the Judicial Committee held in Rangachari v. Secretary of State 1  and in Venkatarao v. Secretary of State 2  that those opening words of section 96B 1  did number qualify the unfettered discretion of the Crown to dismiss a servant at pleasure and that the remedy of the servant for the violation of the rules was number by a law suit but by an appeal of an official or political kind.

precedents.cited_proposition: opening words of section 96B(1) of Government of India Act 1919 did not qualify the unfettered discretion of the Crown to dismiss at pleasure; remedy for violation of rules is official or political appeal not lawsuit

Secretary of State 2  that those opening words of section 96B 1  did number qualify the unfettered discretion of the Crown to dismiss a servant at pleasure and that the remedy of the servant for the violation of the rules was number by a law suit but by an appeal of an official or political kind. Then came the Government of India Act, 1935.

The position, therefore, is that both under the rules and according to the last mentioned decision of the Judicial Committee there is numberdistinction between a dismissal and a removal except that the former disqualifies from future employment while the latter does number.

precedents.case_name: I. M. Lal v Secretary of State
precedents.cited_proposition: removal falls within section 240(3) of Government of India Act 1935 implying removal comprised within dismissal

precedents.case_name: Satischandra Anand v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: dismissal and removal used in same sense in article 311; article 311 does not apply to all terminations of service such as termination of temporary contract service
precedents.cited_holding: article 311 has no application to termination of temporary contract service

precedents.citation: Satishchandra Anand v. The Union of India supra

anchor.surface_text: Our recent decision in Satishchandra Anand v. The Union of India  supra  fully supports the conclusion that article 311 does number apply to all cases of. termination of service. That was a case of a companytract for temporary service being terminated by numberice under one of the clauses of the companytract itself and fell within clause  c  of the Explanation to rule 49 and article 311 was held by this Court number to have any application to the case.

precedents.case_name: Satischandra Anand v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: article 311 does not apply to termination of service under temporary contract
